Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will use observations of transiting planets in order to measure fundamental stellar and exoplanet parameters, and to measure higher-order effects of the star-planet interactions, such as irradiation, non-sphericity, phase lags, and transit timing variations. They will model measurements of light-curves using high-precision photometry provided by the Kepler mission, along with orbital dynamics codes, in order to constrain models of stellar and planetary structure. They will also perform multicolor photometry at nearby Mt. Laguna Observatory to complement the single color light curves from Kepler and ultimately provide better temperature and radii measurements of eclipsing binary stars.

The proposal explains that this work will have a broader significance to the field in that it will provide tools and detailed measurements of stellar properties at a higher precision than currently available. Since uncertainty in planetary masses and radii ultimately depends on how well the parent star's mass and radius are determined, analysis and modeling of the data on the stars will be useful to other exoplanetary projects. The investigators will also integrate research and education by involving undergraduate and graduate students and discuss their research in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcome of this NSF funding is that it has enabled us to develop a whole new area of research in astronomy, the field of "circumbinary planets". Circumbinary planets are planets that orbit around two stars, like the fictional planet Tatooine from the film Star Wars. Over the course of the past four years, we have been directly responsible for discovering six new circumbinary planets (Kepler-34b ,35b ,38b, 47b, 47c, and 453b) and have played key roles in the analysis and understanding of three other planets (Kepler-16b, 64b, 413b). We have been co-authors on every transiting circumbinary planet discovery paper to date. These detections have firmly establish a new class of  planetary system. We have found that circumbinary planets are not rare: we estimate there are at least hundreds of millions of such systems in our galaxy. These results are leading to a much better theoretical understanding of planet formation and orbital evolution, of close-binary star formation, and of what it means to be in a habitable zone. In addition to these planet discoveries, we are obtaining some of the most precise measurements of the masses and radii of low-mass stars.

Along with publishing our results and presenting our work at professional conferences, we have shared our discoveries with the general public via numerous public outreach talks, newpaper and magazines articles, and radio show appearances. We have shared our discoveries and excitement with many students in our college classes for non-science majors, and of course we have advised and trained our graduate and undergraduate research students.
